text:
No clue how to spitball a magnitude of improvement, but I'd argue that it is on the positive side.

But when it comes to forecasting, I think XML was too complex, but JSON is too simple. Comments, yes, but also some sort of in-band indication of references and annotations would be quite welcome. Or maybe we just need a new standard format birthed by a language that has richer data (and thus richer literals) than JS.

elements.text:

But when it comes to forecasting, I think XML was too complex, but JSON is too simple. Comments, yes, but also some sort of in-band indication of references and annotations would be quite welcome. Or maybe we just need a new standard format birthed by a language that has richer data (and thus richer literals) than JS.

text: I suspect the most of positive impact was incidental to JSON itself as a format and was driven by the shift from "web services" and "enterprise service bus" architectures to REST and Microservice architectures. Though we're going back from REST to RPC (JSON-RPC, gRPC) more and more, and I'm not sure it's a good thing. But we'll see.

elements.text: I suspect the most of positive impact was incidental to JSON itself as a format and was driven by the shift from "web services" and "enterprise service bus" architectures to REST and Microservice architectures. Though we're going back from REST to RPC (JSON-RPC, gRPC) more and more, and I'm not sure it's a good thing. But we'll see.

text:
I agree with <@UC2A2ARPT> that XML is too complex (in spite of being the simplification of SGML, which is perhaps the ideal example for showcasing overengineering) and JSON too simple. An interesting intermediate is STON (<https://github.com/svenvc/ston/blob/master/ston-paper.md|Smalltalk Object Notation>), which is indeed the idea of JSON applied to a language with a richer data model.
But there is another, perhaps orthogonal difference. XML was never meant to be a dump of some data structure. It always includes some metadata, in the form of tags. Pretty much all XML documents contain information that you could just throw away if you only care about data exchange between two software agents.

attachments.title: ston/ston-paper.md at master · svenvc/ston
attachments.text: STON - Smalltalk Object Notation - A lightweight text-based, human-readable data interchange format for class-based object-oriented languages like Smalltalk. - ston/ston-paper.md at master · svenvc...

Smalltalk Object Notation

), which is indeed the idea of JSON applied to a language with a richer data model.
But there is another, perhaps orthogonal difference. XML was never meant to be a dump of some data structure. It always includes some metadata, in the form of tags. Pretty much all XML documents contain information that you could just throw away if you only care about data exchange between two software agents.

text:
Checking in after being preoccupied... two thoughts:

<@UBSMEUXAA> is spot on with "VR device being just a monitor" being a bad idea.  I really, really hope that medium appropriate spacial affordances are developed before the hardware becomes good enough to easily read small text.  Nothing will disappoint me more than us settling for the projection of innumerable 80x24 terminal windows.

<@U013ZLJARC7> makes a good point with "insurmountable problems with current VR tech ... motion sickness."  Despite strongly preferring VR to AR, I can wear a HoloLens comfortably for a lot longer than a Quest.  Long term, I would feel better about an operating system that guarantees frame rate rather than relying on experience** developers.

** Can't bring myself to use the word "app."

Long term, I would feel better about an operating system that guarantees frame rate rather than relying on experience** developers.

** Can't bring myself to use the word "app."

text:
One headache with XML is that a 90% parser is roughly as tricky as JSON, but that last 10% is a lot of work for little benefit.

Another headache is more accidental complexity.  Do you go with `<tag property="value">more stuff</tag>` or `<tag><property>value</property><more>more stuff</more></tag>` or whatever else?  JSON has this quality too, but to a lesser degree.

elements.text:
One headache with XML is that a 90% parser is roughly as tricky as JSON, but that last 10% is a lot of work for little benefit.

Another headache is more accidental complexity.  Do you go with
<tag property="value">more stuff</tag>
or
<tag><property>value</property><more>more stuff</more></tag>
or whatever else?  JSON has this quality too, but to a lesser degree.

text: Interesting that nobody has mentioned protobuf. I have no attachment to protobuf itself, but if I don't need my data to be human readable in its serialized form (which I usually don't), I prefer an encoding that is easier for the computer to work with, faster to parse, and, most importantly, structured and typed. After 12 years of Javascript, I've had enough headaches originating from the fact that my objects are an amorphous unstructured soup.

elements.text: Interesting that nobody has mentioned protobuf. I have no attachment to protobuf itself, but if I don't need my data to be human readable in its serialized form (which I usually don't), I prefer an encoding that is easier for the computer to work with, faster to parse, and, most importantly, structured and typed. After 12 years of Javascript, I've had enough headaches originating from the fact that my objects are an amorphous unstructured soup.

text: You make a good point about being structured and typed.  I haven't had network infrastructure fast enough or messages big enough that "easier for the computer to work with" proved a bottleneck.  Only for stuff run locally, has any sort of parsing overhead proven problematic in my twenty some years of professional programming.  (Of course, I'm just one guy with one small firm's specific needs.)

text:
Depends on what you do. The case of "messages big enough" is pretty frequent in my field (computational science). And yet, whenever I work with binary serialization formats, there comes the point where it's a pain to debug some problem.

As for "typed": is that in practice a real advantage of protobuf compared to, say, JSON or XML with schema-based validation?

text: <https://reasonablypolymorphic.com/blog/protos-are-wrong/> :wink:
Think it has to do easier ORM to typed class or native collections. With XML the question of if a value should be an attribute or a element and the consequences of getting wrong slowed me down.

elements.text: Think it has to do easier ORM to typed class or native collections. With XML the question of if a value should be an attribute or a element and the consequences of getting wrong slowed me down.

text:
<https://formik.org> and <https://formium.io>, bur for react only. I’ll be crafting some sort of form tool myself soon. My aim is to use cross-framework <https://xstate.js.org> to manage state and I want it to automatically have backend validation out of box, i.e. forms and backend(+frontend) validation generated out automatically (using pydantic for python or zod for typescript).

Whilst thinking about it, I think django might have got it right in terms of architecture (models, modelforms, form widgets, so it’ll be just deciding what has to replace each part.

I also know that i’ll be using <https://www.storyblok.com> for all the orchestration of all the missing pieces, it’s my base of all low-code platforms and it’s where I will have my forms built using drag-n-drop components.

Chances are I’ll come up with something in the comming few weeks, will try to share outcomes in this thread.

P.S. Could you elaborate on `JSON exports / Unreadable code generation - This just kills most solutions for me.` - not sure I fully what you meant with this.

text: Anyone here is interested in SAT, 3-SAT, Complexity, P vs NP? I was looking everywhere for a particular version of 3-SAT algo that I am thinking of (although it is not totally done in my mind) and I would like to understand what am I missing (or not seeing rather) because it does seem to me that there is a nice (i guess) polynomial time (I hope) algo to deal with 3-SAT. Now 3-SAT being NP Complete and the fact that all NP-Complete problems can be reduced to 3-SAT in polynomial time, I am certainly off somewhere. The problem is, I can't figure out where. So was thinking to talk with someone with experience in this area...

text: <@U02ADH37E02>  <https://formium.io/>  fits my usecase for the design part but not the email triggers / db crud part. I am using wordpress forms to get the effect of formium for now. Webflow has a nice designer and database but the exported code  looks weird (see screenshot). Ideally I would like to self host, connect to existing dbs and use tailwind / bootstrap / plain html5 based code without all the weird ids. Perhaps html comments could be used to identify blocks of code instead of  `<div id="w…."`  and changing css text also changes the numbers in the properties.

text: In the project that I am currently hired by, I have build a form solution using formik and because Kentico is used as a cms , it is easy to send emails after form submits. It also has a marketing automation flow editor which can be used if you need more then just a simple email. Kentico is not the cheapest cms. The site that I am working on is <http://fnv.nl|fnv.nl> .. which is the biggest union here in the netherlands, so it is in dutch. Formik is definitely something I can recommend using. Although I've done a lot of custom work to build the features that we needed (visibility conditions and multi step form handling)
